facts.text: Writ Petition No. 218 of 1971 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 218 of 1971 Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus

facts.text: Petition challenges detention under West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: This petition under Article 32 challenges the detention under the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, 1970  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Petition and others adjourned till decision in State of West Bengal v Ashok Dey Ors.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that this and other Writ Petitions were adjourned till the decision of this Court on the validity and vires of the Act which has number been decided in the State of West Betir gal v Ashok Dey Ors. etc.etc

facts.text: In State of West Bengal v Ashok Dey, Court held Act does not contravene Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In that case it, has been held that the provisions of the Act do number companytravene any of the mandates of the Constitution, as such this Petition and the others which had stood over till that decision have companye up for companysideration

facts.text: Three main contentions urged: mandatory provisions complied with, grounds irrelevant/vague, confirmation within 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: In this and other petitions three main companytentions have been urged on behalf of the respective petitioners by Shri S. K. Mehta who is assisting us as Amicus Curiae. They are  i  Whether the mandatory provisions of the, Act have been companyplied with  ii  whether the grounds are irrelevant or vague and  iii

facts.text: Shri S. K. Mehta assisting as Amicus Curiae.

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of the respective petitioners by Shri S. K. Mehta who is assisting us as Amicus Curiae.

facts.text: Detention order made by District Magistrate, Bankura on 16-01-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was made by the District Magistrate, Bankura on 16-1-71 and petitioner was arrested on 20-1-71.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 20-01-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was made by the District Magistrate, Bankura on 16-1-71 and petitioner was arrested on 20-1-71.

facts.text: On 20-01-1971, petitioner served with order and grounds of detention.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day he was served with the order and the grounds of detention.

facts.text: District Magistrate made report to State Government on 20-01-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate made a report to the Government also on the same day which was approved by the State Government on 27-1-71

facts.text: State Government approved detention on 27-01-1971.

anchor.surface_text: which was approved by the State Government on 27-1-71 so that the mandatory provisions of the Act both in respect of the report to be made to the State Government within 5 days from the date of the order and the approval of the detention within 12 days from the date of detention were satisfied.

facts.text: Report made to Central Government on 27-01-1971.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th itself a report was made to the Central Government as required under section 13.

facts.text: Detention placed before Advisory Board on 18-02-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government placed the detention order, the grounds and the report etc. before the Advisory Board on the 18th February 1971

facts.text: State Government rejected detenue's representation on 15-03-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government rejected the representation made by the detenue on the 15th March1971

facts.text: Advisory Board submitted report on 23-03-1971 that there was sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: and the Advisory Board submitted its report that there was sufficient cause.for his detention on the 23rd March 1971 which was companyfirmed on 8-4-71.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention on 08-04-1971.

anchor.surface_text: which was companyfirmed on 8-4-71.

facts.text: Confirmation communicated to detenue on 26-08-1971.

anchor.surface_text: In the numbere file of the Government which we  1  1952 S.C.R. 612.  2  1964 S.C.R.205. perused, though companyfirmation was recorded within three months, the companymunication was made later on the 26th August 1971.

facts.text: On 07-01-1971 night, petitioner and associates mutilated statue of Rabindra Nath Tagore at Boilapara, Bishnupur.

anchor.surface_text: that on 7-1-71 night you and your associates including Somesh Chandra Deb mutilated the statue of the eminent Indian Poet Rabindra Nath Tagore installed in a public place at Boilapara in Bishnupur town and thereby caused insult to an object of public veneration.

facts.text: On 11-01-1971 at 01:45 hrs, petitioner and associates broke into Post Office at Rashikguni, Bishnupur, caused mischief by fire, destroyed records.

anchor.surface_text: That on 11-1-71 at about 01.45 hrs. you and your associates broke into the Post Office situated at Rashikguni in Bishnupur town and caused mischief to it by fire by destroying its official records by burning.

facts.text: Court perused government file confirming confirmation recorded within three months.

anchor.surface_text: In the numbere file of the Government which we perused, though companyfirmation was recorded within three months, the companymunication was made later on the 26th August 1971.

facts.text: Court held mandatory provisions of Act fully complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The mandatory provisions, therefore, are fully companyplied with.

facts.text: Court held grounds not vague or irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the grounds are vague and irrelevant. These are as follows- ... We think there is numbervalidity in this submission.

facts.text: Petitioner contends associates not specified making representation difficult.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended that the associates of the petitioner have number been specified and therefore it will be difficult for the petitioner to make effective representation in respect thereof.

facts.text: Court rejected contention that acts affect only law and order, not public order.

anchor.surface_text: It is again companytended relying on Madhu Limaye v. Sub-Divi- sional Magistrate, Monghyr and others 1  and Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar and Ors.  2  that the acts specified in each of the grounds do number amount to disturbance of public order though they may affect law and order. This companytention is equally untenable

facts.text: Section 3(2)(c) of Act covers acts causing insult to object of public veneration like statue.

anchor.surface_text: We are here in this case companycerned with the definition given in section 3  2   c  which makes any act causing insult to the Indian National Flag or to any other object of public veneration whether by mutilating, damaging, burning, defiling, destroying or otherwise

facts.text: Validity of Section 3(2) upheld in State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of subsection  2  of section 3 of the Act was challenged recently in the case of State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey and others 3 , but this Court held that it was valid.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Jaganmohan Reddy J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Jaganmhan Reddy J.

facts.text: K. Mehta for petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: K. Mehta, for the petitioner.

facts.text: N. Mukherjee, G. S. Chatterjee and Sukumar Basu for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: N. Mukherjee, G. S. Chatterjee and Sukumar Basu, for the respondent.

facts.text: Court agrees confirmation must be within three months from detention date.

anchor.surface_text: In our view therefore the companyfirmation of the opinion of the Advisory Board to companytinue the detention beyond three months must be within three months from the date of detention

arguments.claim: Section 3(2) of the Act is valid as held in State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey

anchor.surface_text: The validity of subsection 2 of section 3 of the Act was challenged recently in the case of State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey and others , but this Court held that it was valid.

holdings.text: The confirmation of the opinion of the Advisory Board to continue the detention beyond three months must be within three months from the date of detention in conformity with the mandate in clause 4 of Article 22.

anchor.surface_text: In our view therefore the confirmation of the opinion of the Advisory Board to continue the detention beyond three months must be within three months from the date of detention in conformity with the mandate in clause  4  of Article 22.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 22(4) mandates Board report within 3 months for extension; purposive reading of ss.12-13 requires govt confirmation within 3 months to extend detention; supported by precedents under analogous provisions.

holdings.text: The confirmation must result in an objective recorded action in writing, not a mere mental or subjective act.

anchor.surface_text: the State Government has to confirm the opinion of the Board that there is cause for the detention of the person concerned which confirmation cannot purely be a mental act, a subjective one but must result in an objective action namely that it should be recorded in writing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consonant with Act, Constitution, and precedents requiring formal objective orders; distinguishes mental processes from recorded decisions.

holdings.text: There is no requirement to communicate the confirmation to the detenue within three months from the date of detention; communication must be within a reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: While we consider the former submission to be valid the latter has no justification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual warrant in Act or Art.22(4); precedents under similar provisions do not require timely communication absent prejudice; desirable but irregularity at most.

holdings.text: The mandatory provisions of the Act have been fully complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The mandatory provisions, therefore, are fully complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts verified from govt file and dates: service same day, approvals/reports within limits, Board placement timely, confirmation 8-4-71 within 3 months.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention are not vague or irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: We think there is no validity in this submission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds specify dates, times, places, detailed acts; no need to name all associates as detention based on petitioner's acts.

holdings.text: The acts specified in the grounds amount to disturbance of public order under section 3(2)(c) of the Act, not merely law and order.

anchor.surface_text: This contention is equally untenable because section 3 2  of the Act defines the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutilation of public statue and arson at post office cause insult to object of public veneration per s.3(2)(c); falls under public order; follows Madhu Limaye/Lohia distinction and Ashok Dey upholding provision.

holdings.text: Section 3(2) of the Act, including clause (c), is valid.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of subsection  2  of section 3 of the Act was challenged recently in the case of State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey and others 3 , but this Court held that it was valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent from State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey directly upholding provision against constitutional challenge.

anchor.surface_text: In our view therefore the confirmation of the opinion of the Advisory Board to continue the detention beyond three months must be within three months from the date of detention in conformity with the mandate in clause  4  of Article 22.

edges.explanation: Resolving the issue of mandatory compliance requires consideration of Section 3(5) WBPVAA.
Issue of whether mandatory provisions complied with requires the concept of Section 8 WBPVAA compliance.
Resolving whether mandatory provisions were complied with requires consideration of compliance with Section 11 WBPVAA as in c8.
The issue on compliance with mandatory provisions of the Act addresses Section 13 WBPVAA (maximum period after confirmation) as the core concept in this cluster
Issue on vagueness of grounds requires application of natural justice doctrine standards for specificity of grounds.
The issue of timely confirmation requires the Advisory Board report under Section 11 WBPVAA as described in c8.
Determining if the acts amount to disturbance of public order or only law and order under section 3(2)(c) requires applying the rational nexus test for Clause 3(2)(c).
